div.p:
Narrator:
A single choice. A deceptively normal decision. A split second. Shattering consequences… This story involves two families hundreds of miles apart and the indescribable riptide of a single choice on all of their lives. Both families have been touched by a tragedy, but each in its own way… In suburban Atlanta, the Jordens struggle to return to something close to normal.

Mom:
6.5 years ago...remember that piece of history. We had two children at home, his younger brother and sister. His older brother was already out on his own, Derrick was at FAU.

Dad:
We had the rest of the family back here; his younger brother and sister were living at home and going to school. They were both active swimmers too, so carting them around to swim practice and the other normal everyday activities: school, church, keeping the lids on all the jars.

Mom:
Derrick was always an adventurer. He was always putting himself in as many places—the consummate multitasker. We always knew that if he had something he wanted to do he had the facilities to make it happen for himself.

Dad:
One of the things we’ve tried to explain to our children is it’s up to them what they want to do with their lives. … We felt no matter what he was going to do, he was establishing a good foundation and would be able to do just about whatever he put his mind to do. He’d already expressed an interest in theater, but the world was his oyster.

Narrator:
The Jordens were a military family. Karl is a former marine pilot.

Mom:
I think partially b/c with his military career and moving every 3 years—we had four children and they were each other’s best friends, they had to be. When you moved to a new place, the comfort zone was home. It made them very close, normal sibling rivalry but very close that way.

Lisa:
Well I’m the youngest of four kids, my name is Lisa. I’m a sister….I’m the youngest. 3 older brothers, I’m the little sister. Our family has always been extremely close, everyone in our family is a family person and would do anything for anybody in a heartbeat. I can remember in middle school you used to be allowed to invite people to come eat lunch with you. Derrick would probably come 3-4 times a month to come have lunch with me. My friends would say my brothers don’t do that, why does your brother, you’re so lucky, and I’d be like yeah, I am.

Kyle:
My brother was a senior in high school, … we went to the same high school. On the swim team together and participated in a lot of activities together and had a lot of good times together. … he had gone off to school and I was finishing up my high school season and looking to go off to college and follow him down to FL. That all changed …

Aaron:
His parents and my aunt and uncle grew up together. …have known Derrick for 13-14 years now… I think my uncle and his dad flew fighter pilots for the Marines. Some of the things I admire most about this kid were his honesty and his loyalty. …We did spend a lot of time talking about what kind of things we wanted to do once we got through the school part of life.

Bradley:
We've been the closest siblings growing up in our family. We're military, moved around a lot, didn't keep a lot of the same friends so through that always gravitated toward each other b/c we always had each other there through our major changes, we had each other to depend on. We're closer than my other brother and sister. That's why it's such a hard state of affairs to wrap your hands around I guess.

Lisa:
July 25, wow, that was one day I’ll never forget. …My mom came in at 7 or 8 am, pretty early, and said you need to pack your suitcase for a couple days, we gotta go to FL. Why, what’s wrong I asked. She said Derrick got in an accident and we need to go now, …She said Derrick is…and when she said that my heart just drops and my throat –it was horrible—…

Mom:
Kind of a blur, a fog, living through the fog, living in numbness. … This was someplace we’d never been, never had any experience with, we didn’t know what to do, what not to do.

Lisa:
At that point I just knew things were about to change, life was going to be different.

Kyle:
My initial thoughts when I first heard about the incident was that nothing was ever going to be the same. This was going to be something that for the rest of our lives would change every aspect of what we do and who we are.

Bradley:
It was later on at night, I got a phone call from my younger brother Kyle…Right then my heart, just b/c of what time of night it was, it gave me this pit, something’s-not-right feeling in my stomach. …I can't even put my hand on it, almost just an emptiness and Oh my God what happens now with all of us?

Dad:
I answered the phone and it was Derrick on the other end. I think the first words out of his mouth were, “Dad, it’s like you said, something’s happened that’s going to change my life forever.” I didn’t, I was like what? What are you talking about? He said, “I was in a car crash.”

Derrick:
My name is Derrick Jorden. I’m an inmate in the FL Dept of Corrections, DC number W26096. I’ve been in the Dept of corrections now for over 4 years. … Here for DUI manslaughter. Accident happened in 2002, … I was 20 years old at the time. When I was in high school, my mom and dad were pretty strict and I couldn’t get away with too much drinking.

Narrator:
When Derrick was 17, he moved to Boca Raton to attend Florida Atlantic University. It was there that he decided he wanted to pursue a degree in theatre.

Derrick:
Then when I was 17 and went on down to Florida, and went to college it opened up. It was wide open. … I handled it responsibly most times, but occasionally it would get a little out of hand I guess. So, the day of the accident I was working as a valet parker, parking cars at the golf course. …A couple beers on the golf course, that just seemed to be part of the ritual, … I wasn’t even of legal drinking age at this time and we went out to this steak house and had dinner and more beers.

Narrator:
It was “two-dollar pitcher night” at a local bar. Derrick paid a bouncer to let him in, and he drank there until 2AM.

Derrick:
… now I’m thinking man what am I gonna do, I need to be at work in the morning. …So I thought well the best idea is to head on home. I’m probably ok to drive, so I got in the car and buckled up. Turned on the lights and took off. I guess the last thing I remember was seeing, this was south Florida where they got these long straight road and you can see green lights all the way down them, or traffic lights anyway, sometimes they’re red. But they were green as far as I could see and that’s kinda the last vision I remember having. I guess somewhere along the way one of em must have turned red. Maybe I wasn’t awake or conscious enough to see it, and the next sensation I had was a bit of a crunching kind of feeling but I didn’t really know what was going on. …

Narrator:
Beyond the blur of emergency lights, the severity of the accident was shocking. The front end of Derrick’s car was smashed and the vehicle was almost cut in half. Flames pierced the night as he escaped his burning vehicle. The other car was obliterated. Every panel and every window was smashed, and all the wheels had come off. It was determined that Derrick was traveling at over 80 miles per hour when he hit the other car.

Derrick:
…when the sheriff’s deputy came into my hospital room to talk to me, and—made me feel very small the way he spoke to me, and that I had indeed done something wrong. …when I first heard that somebody died, it –that was a shock, that was a shock. I don’t remember reacting too much other than a silent gasp and oh my god, this can’t be. Having some drinks and getting behind the wheel. We all know it’s wrong and but who’d have ever thought it would have happened to me.

Dad:
This was going to be something that was going to affect our entire family. Obviously, it’s nothing you ever plan for or think about, it always happens to someone else. I couldn’t imagine what was happening to the other family that was involved, the family whose son had been unfortunately killed in the accident.

Narrator:
Dannyel Passeto – the young man who died in the accident – was not alone in the car that night. He was with his friends. And his older brother was behind the wheel.

Derrick:
The guy was 20 years old. He was a lot like me judging from his stories from his friends and the reports I read, he was a lot like me. I wish I would’ve known him, I feel like we would have gotten along all right.

Dad:
We’ve obviously never been confronted w/ anything even remotely similar to this and we want them to know how bad we feel, how sorry we are, how terrible this event is.

Kyle:
I’ve felt for the other family. You don’t have words. You don’t even know what to do…If that had been my brother that was killed, I would be devastated. I’d have had a lot of anger for whoever caused this on me.

Narrator:
Originally from Brazil, the Passeto family lives in Boca Raton. In addition to his brother, Dennys, Dannyel had a twin sister -Gabryella.

Lisa:
You know I couldn’t even imagine being in her position. It has to be so hard to—I mean you know how they say twins have that special bond and there’s always parts of each other but, I couldn’t imagine what it’s like for her and the pain that she feels.

Narrator:
Derrick pled guilty to the charge of DUI manslaughter, so there was no trial. But the sentencing hearing – two and a half years after the accident – was a heart-wrenching culmination of grief, anger, remorse, and loss.

Derrick:
His siblings were just livid, almost rage I could see. They were that upset. His brother looked me right in the eyes and he said, “You gotta pay, man. YOU gotta pay.”

Dad:
The best word to describe it is surrealistic. You don’t ever imagine it. When it’s happening you go I can’t believe I’m doing this. But you know the finality of it that at the end of the day he’d probably be led off in handcuffs. And that was what happened.

Lisa:
The day of the hearing was without a doubt one of the worst days of my life. [Crying] It was really, really hard b/c the other family was just putting him down and saying that he was just the worst person in the whole world and he just deserved to sit in a jail cell … So it was just—I know what a good person he is, and what a good heart he has, so to hear everyone else just put him down b/c they don’t know him b/c of this tragic accident, was really really hard.

Bradley:
To see the emotion from the other family and from my brother… To hear Dannyel Passeto's mom say she couldn't stand locking the door at night b/c she felt she was locking her son out of the house. To try to put yourself in their shoes was overwhelming. Absolutely overwhelming.

Derrick:
His mother was there. …I remember looking at her in the eyes and trying to tell her through just my eyes and through everything that I had in me that I wasn’t this monster that you know, that she probably thought that I was. And I hope that she could forgive me someday.

Kyle:
It was just probably one of the most emotionally taxing days of my life and I can almost positively say it was the same for everybody else in our family and in the victim’s family, family and friends.

Derrick:
They had not just the family but a lot of friends as well. …and so I walked in and they all had these t-shirts with his picture, and huge big giant color picture all the way across the t-shirt, and at the bottom it said “killed by a drunk driver.” And they all sat right in the front row … That hit home, that hit home.

Aaron:
When I found out how long it was going to be, you kind of look and try to put that into the perspective of how long he’s going to have to spend in a jail cell vs. how long the victim’s family was going to have to spend without their son, or their brother or their best friend… there were losses that were going to have to be incurred b/c of his actions.

Derrick:
His sister told how she’d had a few birthdays since the accident, … And she dreads it now. … It’s not about presents and going out to a fancy restaurant and getting dressed up with your family. That’s not what it’s about anymore, for her it’s about her dead brother. So, my family is the lucky family. And it’s just torn us apart.

Narrator:
The financial cost from this high-risk choice has been overwhelming…

Dad:
So far it has probably been in excess of $200,000. That’s probably a conservative figure b/c that doesn’t even include money for all the things that are ongoing now.

Derrick:
The money is a superficial thing that comes and goes, we’ve all been through that with the economic situation right now. Hopefully I can make some money when I do get out and hopefully pay back Mom and Dad.

Narrator:
But it’s the human cost of Derrick’s decision that has had an immeasurable impact on him and his loved ones. Opportunities and experiences – forever lost. Reputations and relationships – forever changed. The stigma of always being known as a drunk driver who killed someone.

Derrick:
Some of the things are hard to put into words…forever I’ll have this label of drunk driver—drunk driver killer—not even just that I got a DUI but a DUI manslaughter. That’s just horrendous. We don’t have the time to always look through and always find the true character. So I think that the biggest loss, it’s kind of abstract, kind of intangibles or something. You won’t really ever know some of the biggest losses, your personal losses, what doors might have opened, what paths might have been available that are now overgrown, that are now shut down, gates closed, not gonna happen. The friendships, the relationships that might have blossomed.…But man just that one night, man just that one night! All the pain, the ripple effect it’s sent out. A new idea has come up to where a ripple could’ve gone. These are things that you won’t ever see, couldn’t ever really know, … but there’s other ways and just the little waves of that ripple have crept into people’s lives and just passed on and on. … I think it took a toll on my mother physically.

Mom:
Even though we try to keep him involved in our home and family, he’s still missing all the nuances and those connections and those moments. You can’t get those back.

Kyle:
He missed my brother’s wedding, missed my niece’s birth, I’ve been engaged now I’m trying to look to get married, trying to fit all this stuff in and maybe work him into that. Derrick made a mistake. It was Derrick’s choice … He’s paying for his mistake, and he will always be paying for his mistake. That’s his burden that he has to live with.

Derrick:
My sister, my baby sister who has looked up to me for ages, she’s worried about me.

Lisa:
For my family it was very hard b/c it was one of those things that this is either gonna tear you apart or bring you closer. There was no way we were gonna let it tear us apart. [Crying] I knew that I was very scared b/c Derrick and I were very very close and so the thought of him not being there or not being able to interact with him was very scary.

Derrick:
One thing that bothers me is how other people in society might look at my family knowing what I did. So they’re having to pay for my mistake in a way. I mean in a very major way they’re paying for my mistake too. Every day that I’m in here and they’ve got to worry about me, they’re paying for my mistake…

Dad:
I think the biggest think we have lost is that sense of innocence and hope for our family. …We have a pretty close-knit family and a lot of those bonds were strained by this. That has been lost, you can’t regain—you can look at the pictures but it’s not quite the same.

Derrick:
I haven’t really spent any special occasions with my family. … My mother’s 50th birthday was one of the big ones. … I’m not a big crier, not big on tears, but that broke me down that time, to see my mom, for her 50th birthday had to come see me in prison. She had to drive up to this scary looking place with razor wire, …walk in, the guards want to pat her down and they’re not very kind to say the least. …That one broke my heart. That wasn’t the way I wanted my mom to spend her 50th birthday.

Bradley:
I know when he wakes up every morning, there's something he loses every morning before he even gets up and gets going. [Crying a little]. He's lost out on probably one of the biggest thing was his good name--he was Derrick Jorden, gone to high school, done well, gone on to college. The main thing is I've lost "I can be your big brother, I can be there. I've gone down the road sooner that you've gone down. This is what you can do and what you shouldn't do." He's in a place where I haven't been and I don't know what it's like. … It's all the little stuff you start picking up on and that's one of the biggest treasures that Derrick's not had is being able to see all those little things all the time.

Aaron:
The last 4 years you talk about your early 20s are some of the best years of your life, you’re getting all this freedom and responsibility. ….Those are things that he’ll never be able to come back and experience. … I’m getting married in June and this kid who without question should be my best man unfortunately won’t be able to be there for that.

Derrick:
There’s going to be a beautiful photo album and a ton of pictures and I won’t be in any one of them. And those pictures will be there forever. Those pictures will be there as long as he’s on the earth and probably beyond that, and I won’t be, I will never be in his wedding album. I’ll never be in my brother’s either, and the pictures from my mother’s 50th birthday, or the pictures from my sister’s graduation and the big party they had at the house. … The only pictures that I’ve been in in the past 4 years is Polaroids. Plain Polaroids of me standing in this blue outfit, with my mom or my sister or my brothers… They’re not that cool. … it took me a while to ever say, I was drinking and driving and I killed somebody. It took me a while to say that b/c I didn’t want the blame, and to assume the responsibility of taking another person’s life is massive and something that I don’t think anybody that hasn’t done could understand.
